Bug.Summery: Internal error adding CVS project over existing

Lines.Line: 1. Add swt as external project (via PDE)
2. Connect to dev.eclipse.org CVS repository
3. Add swt project from CVS repository
==> Internal error dialog appears:
4 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 Problems encountered while deleting resources.
4 org.eclipse.core.resources 273 Could not delete:
D:\eclipse_I-20020328\plugins\org.eclipse.swt\os.
OK - I now see what happend (you can argue that it is the correct behavior :-)

Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020328
1. Add swt as external project (via PDE) 2. Connect to dev.eclipse.org CVS repository 3. Add swt project from CVS repository ==> Internal error dialog appears: Log: Tue Apr 02 15:37:13 GMT+02:00 2002 4 org.eclipse.core.resources 4 Problems encountered while deleting resources. 1=============<children>============= 4 org.eclipse.core.resources 273 Could not delete: D:\eclipse_I-20020328\plugins\org.eclipse.swt\os. 1=============</children>============= OK - I now see what happend (you can argue that it is the correct behavior :-)
Since I added swt as external project via PDE the project location was a subdirectory of my actual Eclipse INSTALL plugins directory and not my workspace directory. Therefore it could of course not delete os resources like DLLs.
An additional warning in such a case (i.e. where I start to add a project from VCM over a project which is not located inside the workspace itself) would be nice.
Changing from major to enhancement to reflect Daniel's comments.
Marking future (not for 2.0). This seems more like a PDE workflow problem. Reopening to close PDE was changed to always copy plugins when importing

Bug.Summery: javadoc export - small bug in wizard

Lines.Line: 1. File -> Export -> Javadoc
2. then click on "next".
At this point the "finish" button should be enabled.
3. Now click the "Style Sheet" checkbox two times.
4. The "finish" button is disabled now and no way to enable it again (except
perhaps chosing a valid style sheet).

Bug.WithStack:
I am using build 20020321.
Do the following: 1. File -> Export -> Javadoc 2. then click on "next". At this point the "finish" button should be enabled. 3. Now click the "Style Sheet" checkbox two times. 4. The "finish" button is disabled now and no way to enable it again (except perhaps chosing a valid style sheet).
Clicking on "Overview" twice should do the same... fixed. JRT.

Bug.Summery: JavaIndexing time consuming on import
Bug.WithStack:
When you choose to import all of Eclipse with source the JavaIndexing thread will take 204,248 ms (about 3 1/2 minutes) with auto build off.
With auto build on it takes 511,958 ms (about 8 1/2 minutes) - perhaps turning it off for the duration of the import and then doing a bebuild all afterwards might help. WorkspaceModelManager spends 6990 ms processing resource changes regardless most of that is in createWortkspacePluginModel (4786 ms). Moving to PDE/UI for comment. PDE needs some time to digest all the plug-ins (parsing the manifests and building the models). This time has been significantly reduced in the default case because the models are loaded directly from the live registry (no parsing is involved). This covers majority of the cases. The rest (targeting another Eclipse application) will still have a parsing hit but due to a less frequent usage is not considered critical.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you choose to import all of Eclipse with source the JavaIndexing thread will take 204,248 ms (about 3 1/2 minutes) with auto build off.
With auto build on it takes 511,958 ms (about 8 1/2 minutes) - perhaps turning it off for the duration of the import and then doing a bebuild all afterwards might help. WorkspaceModelManager spends 6990 ms processing resource changes regardless most of that is in createWortkspacePluginModel (4786 ms). Moving to PDE/UI for comment. PDE needs some time to digest all the plug-ins (parsing the manifests and building the models). This time has been significantly reduced in the default case because the models are loaded directly from the live registry (no parsing is involved). This covers majority of the cases. The rest (targeting another Eclipse application) will still have a parsing hit but due to a less frequent usage is not considered critical.

Bug.Summery: Workspace.endOperation can be very consuming for large operations
Bug.WithStack:
When you import the entire workbench with source using the PDE the Workbench.endOperation method takes 27 168 ms to run. The most time consuming portions are
Workbench.broadcastChanges (21 478 ms) NotificationManager.notify(14 992 ms) Workbench.snapshotIfNeeded (5 690 ms) As a note, the numbers also include the time that all registered IResourceChangeListeners (e.g. Navigator and Task views, etc) take to process the deltas. I sent Tod a copy of our spy plugin, so that he can see how much time is taken by the listeners. I don't think the snapshot time can be improved much, when you think about the magnitude of the change that occurred (presumably many thousands of resources were created). .
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you import the entire workbench with source using the PDE the Workbench.endOperation method takes 27 168 ms to run. The most time consuming portions are
Workbench.broadcastChanges (21 478 ms) NotificationManager.notify(14 992 ms) Workbench.snapshotIfNeeded (5 690 ms) As a note, the numbers also include the time that all registered IResourceChangeListeners (e.g. Navigator and Task views, etc) take to process the deltas. I sent Tod a copy of our spy plugin, so that he can see how much time is taken by the listeners. I don't think the snapshot time can be improved much, when you think about the magnitude of the change that occurred (presumably many thousands of resources were created). .

Bug.Summery: PreferenceManager fires slow propertyChangedEvent when PreferenceStore is updated
Bug.WithStack:
I have created a workbench with all of Eclipse imported with source.
When we save the decorator preference (by enabling the binary decorator) the firePropertyChangedEvent method in PreferenceStore takes 2019 ms. The entire action takes only 2340 ms so this is a significant performance hit. This should be fixed in 20020411. Please verify.
Confirmed that time has been reduced to 10.49% Marking closed
Bug.WithOutStack:
I have created a workbench with all of Eclipse imported with source.
When we save the decorator preference (by enabling the binary decorator) the firePropertyChangedEvent method in PreferenceStore takes 2019 ms. The entire action takes only 2340 ms so this is a significant performance hit. This should be fixed in 20020411. Please verify.
Confirmed that time has been reduced to 10.49% Marking closed

(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:124) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:536)
There may be two bugs here. We should be getting a compilation error for the given snippet (we should never get to the evaluation). Also, JDIFieldVariable shouldn't be throwing an NPE. The first problem was ours. The evaluation engine has checks which discard compiler errors not occurring in the code snippet - this allows the evaluation to continue when there are unavoidable problems in the generated evaluation source code. However, there was a problem in the code snippet generation such that the offsets used to detect if an error occurred inside the snippet were failing.
This has been fixed. Please verify. Verified

Bug.Summery: no help contents displayed
Bug.WithStack:
I'm running Linux and have only Netscape 4.7 installed. When I click on 'Menu->Help->Help Contents' nothing happens. At least an error dialog should show up. Which Linux are you running? The supported Red Had 7.1 and 7.2 should have mozilla or netscape 6 installed. I'm running RedHat 7. AFAIK, Eclipse is supported starting RedHat 6.x. I think the download web page is wrong on that.
Even if it wasn't supported, it should show an error dialog if Mozilla is not installed. I'm sure you can setup RedHat w/o Mozilla... You can plugin more browser adapters into help to support other browsers on a given platform. We provide one for each platform. The installation program for a product will have to ensure that user system meets the requirements.
Supported platforms are here http://eclipse.org/eclipse/eclipse_project_plan_2_0_rev0214.html and supported browsers http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/~checkout~/platform-help- home/eclipse_project_plan_2_0_supported_browsers.html I understand that Netscape 4.7 is not supported. In any case, some feedback must be provided when I click on the menu item 'Help Contents', even if it's only an error dialog saying that there's no working browser available. I don't see why it is a requirement to have a working browser in order to install Eclipse. There are requirements like OS, VM, Windowing system, system browser for Eclipse. If you do not meet them, you are allowed to install, things are just not going to work.
We might later add some check to the Mozilla adapter that would check if Mozilla is installed, rather than just checking OS, before adapter advertises itself as available ( ( IBrowserFactory.isAvailable() ). Added code to check if browser is on the path and display error if not. Should be in the next nightly build (20020425 or later).
Bug.WithOutStack:
I'm running Linux and have only Netscape 4.7 installed. When I click on 'Menu->Help->Help Contents' nothing happens. At least an error dialog should show up. Which Linux are you running? The supported Red Had 7.1 and 7.2 should have mozilla or netscape 6 installed. I'm running RedHat 7. AFAIK, Eclipse is supported starting RedHat 6.x. I think the download web page is wrong on that.
Even if it wasn't supported, it should show an error dialog if Mozilla is not installed. I'm sure you can setup RedHat w/o Mozilla... You can plugin more browser adapters into help to support other browsers on a given platform. We provide one for each platform. The installation program for a product will have to ensure that user system meets the requirements.
Supported platforms are here http://eclipse.org/eclipse/eclipse_project_plan_2_0_rev0214.html and supported browsers http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/~checkout~/platform-help- home/eclipse_project_plan_2_0_supported_browsers.html I understand that Netscape 4.7 is not supported. In any case, some feedback must be provided when I click on the menu item 'Help Contents', even if it's only an error dialog saying that there's no working browser available. I don't see why it is a requirement to have a working browser in order to install Eclipse. There are requirements like OS, VM, Windowing system, system browser for Eclipse. If you do not meet them, you are allowed to install, things are just not going to work.
We might later add some check to the Mozilla adapter that would check if Mozilla is installed, rather than just checking OS, before adapter advertises itself as available ( ( IBrowserFactory.isAvailable() ). Added code to check if browser is on the path and display error if not. Should be in the next nightly build (20020425 or later).

Bug.Summery: Initializing JRE variables slow on plug-in activation

Lines.Line: 1) Start with fresh workbench
2) Turn off the auto build preference
3) Import all of Eclipse using the plugin importer including source
4) Switch to the hava Perspective

Bug.WithStack:
When I do the following
1) Start with fresh workbench 2) Turn off the auto build preference 3) Import all of Eclipse using the plugin importer including source 4) Switch to the hava Perspective
The method org.eclipse.jdt.core.JavaCore.setClasspath variable takes 38222 ms.
updateCycleMarkers takes 30 268 ms of this time.
Please note that these times were gathered using the OptimizeIt tool - benchmarking with a stopwatch indicates that the same operation takes 16 instead of 38 ms without the profiler. This is likely due to the model refresh underneath, triggered by the classpath setting operations. We want to revisit this code anyway. Added a classpath variable setting API allowing to initialize multiple variables at once. In this particular scenario, it will mean 3 times less classpath updates.
Need to investigate more to see actual times with new behavior.
Also: clients of JavaCore#setClasspathVariable should adopt the new API (JavaCore#setClasspathVariables). When running the same test case, I am numbers which aren't so bad. I am in particular seeing 70% of the time inside:
org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.DelegatingURLClassLoader.findClassParents() see attached profile.
Created attachment 545 Profiling switch to Java perspective Performed some changes to improve the performance of multi-variable updates, but even without it, I still cannot reproduce the original numbers.
Also funaced the too many path canonicalizations (internal calls do not need it).
Tod - can you reproduce these numbers after next integration build ? Consider fixed, unless symptoms are reproduceable.

1) Start with fresh workbench 2) Turn off the auto build preference 3) Import all of Eclipse using the plugin importer including source 4) Switch to the hava Perspective

Added a classpath variable setting API allowing to initialize multiple variables at once. In this particular scenario, it will mean 3 times less classpath updates.
Need to investigate more to see actual times with new behavior.
Also: clients of JavaCore#setClasspathVariable should adopt the new API (JavaCore#setClasspathVariables). When running the same test case, I am numbers which aren't so bad. I am in particular seeing 70% of the time inside:

Bug.Summery: Projects imported with source are still binary projects

Lines.Line: 1) Select Import plugins wizard
2) Import all of Eclipse with Source
3) jar files will be imported
4) Select Decorators - Binary Plug In projects
5) They will all show up as Binary.
Fixed. When import with source option is used, project is not marked as binary
and therefore not decorated.

I would be better if the jar file was not imported at all and if the project were not shown as binary.
STEPS 1) Select Import plugins wizard 2) Import all of Eclipse with Source 3) jar files will be imported 4) Select Decorators - Binary Plug In projects 5) They will all show up as Binary. Fixed. When import with source option is used, project is not marked as binary and therefore not decorated.

STEPS 1) Select Import plugins wizard 2) Import all of Eclipse with Source 3) jar files will be imported 4) Select Decorators - Binary Plug In projects 5) They will all show up as Binary. Fixed. When import with source option is used, project is not marked as binary and therefore not decorated.

Bug.Summery: Exception during startup.

Stacktrace.Reason: The root element is required in a well-formed document.

Lines.Line: - Fresh workspace
- Set pref to launcher-style
- Import something and launch
it
- Change pref to config-style
- Exit workbench
- Restarting workbench generates walkback in
log
Fixed in DebugUIPlugin.setEmptyLaunchHistories(). Problem was that on a property change for
the launching preference, we were resetting the histories, but NOT clearing the most recent
launch field. This resulted in writing out bogus XML to the history file on shutdown, which caused
a parse error on startup. I think this little problem may have been the root cause of several other
'XML parse error' bugs that were logged in regards to launch configs.
Fixed.
Please verify.
Verified

Use the plugin import wizard to import plugins. Then the above occured. A trivial problem - fragments were iterated over using the plug-in counter. Fixed and released into HEAD (will appear in the next integration build).
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: 20020328
I had one plugin fragment in my workspace when I used the plugin import tool. When I got to the "Selection" stage of the import wizard I got an error dialog that said "44 >= 1". All I could do was click ok.
Then there was an extra, blank, entry at the top of the list. I checked it and clicked "Add Required Plug-ins". I got the following walkback.
Could you describe your scenario in more detail? I would like to be able to reproduce it (it may be related to the fact that you have a fragment in the workspace). Ah-ha. Upon further examination, I had a plugin fragment in my host eclipse with the same name as the plugin fragment I was creating.
Follow these steps:
1. New workspace 2. In the "Target Platform" preferences, select all non-workspace plugins. 3. Create a plugin fragment named "test". In the creation wizard, make test a fragment of Eclipse Workbench. With a "Compatible" match rule. 4. Export test to the filesystem in /<eclipse install>/fragments 5. Restart Eclipse 6. Use the plugin import wizard to import plugins. Then the above occured. A trivial problem - fragments were iterated over using the plug-in counter. Fixed and released into HEAD (will appear in the next integration build).

Bug.Summery: Performance Issues with TypeSelectionDialog
Bug.WithStack:
The following methods can be slow when opening a TypeSelectionDialog. The workbench in use is a workbench with all of Eclipse loaded.
FilteredList.setElements takes 3547 ms. The TwoArrayQuickSorter takes 2468 ms. TypeInfoLabelProvider.getText() takes 767 ms, most of which is taken up with creation, appending and getting the text from a StringBuffer.
FilteredList.run() takes 848 ms most of which is spent in the setText(372 ms) and setImage(396 ms) methods for TableItem. the dialog is now multi threaded and this isn't an issue anymore.

Bug.Summery: Launch Configuration Dialog: Can't toggle panes if main type is invalid

2. Enter a main class that does not exist
3. try to go to an other tab.
4. This doesn't work, the tab flickers

Bug.WithStack:
20020328 smoke for 20020402 1. Create a new Java application launch config 2. Enter a main class that does not exist 3. try to go to an other tab. 4. This doesn't work, the tab flickers
Why can't I start entering the other fields? It would be better if the other tabs are disabled than to switch back programatically. Agreed, we should disable other tabs when the current tab is in error, rather than doing the "quick flip". This is a good idea, except I can't find any API to disable a tab. Waiting for response from SWT team. Per Steve N., there is no API to disable a TabItem. Any other ideas, or should we just leave in the 'quick flip'? Deferred until we have a better idea. I would allow switching of the panes. The error icon will always be on the top (with apply being disabled). Closed. Error message now appears, and tab switching is allowed. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Performance issues with JavaEditor
Bug.WithStack:
If you open type on org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.parser.Parser if it is not currently visible it will take 36398 ms. I was benchmarking using OptimizeIt so the actual times will be a little better.
The following methods took the most time The JavaOutlineViewer itnernalExpandToLevel took 5729 ms. 3779 ms of that was getting the image for the TreeViewer.
PackageExplorerPart.editorActivated() took 3081 ms, most of which was spent creating TreeItems and decorating them.
TypeHierarchyPart.setInputElement() took 15286 ms. updateMethodViewer() took 2701 ms and ensureRefreshedTypeHierarchy took 11387 ms. Looks more like an outline/tree population problem. Our standard test case is opening the SWT OS class. fixed in M5

Bug.Summery: StringIndexOutOfBoundsException in JUnit's FailureTraceView
Bug.WithStack:
Build: 20020328
Description: I'm running some benchmarks in Eclipse using the JUnit Test Plugins launcher and I occasionally run into situations where my benchmark causes an exception, and JUnit fails to display the stack trace. I think it's because FailureTraceView.fillTable(String trace) assumes that there is I accidentally hit commit....
I think FailureTraceView.fillTable(String trace) assumes that trace contains a '\n', but I'm causing exceptions whose stack traces don't contain a '\n'. This is rather frustrating because I have no way of knowing what exception happened in my test because the StringIndexOutOfBoundsException gets in the way.... the code is not writtern properly needs to be rewritten... made the code more sensitive with regard to newlines. pls try again and reopen bug if you can reproduce the problem.

Bug.Summery: NPE evaluating in static context
Bug.WithStack:
Breakpoint on line 58 Use source in bug 12452. In the variables view detail pane, inspect "InnerAnon.this.description"
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.EvaluationSourceGenerator.getType FromProject(EvaluationSourceGenerator.java:211) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.EvaluationSourceGenerator.getSour ce(EvaluationSourceGenerator.java:129) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine.getCompiledEx pression(ASTEvaluationEngine.java:188) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.eval.ast.engine.ASTEvaluationEngine.evaluate (ASTEvaluationEngine.java:70) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.EvaluateAction.run (EvaluateAction.java:248) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.InspectAction.run (InspectAction.java:79) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.actions.EvaluateAction.run (EvaluateAction.java:550) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.PluginAction.runWithEvent (PluginAction.java:204) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetSelection (ActionContributionItem.java:407) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:361) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.access$0 (ActionContributionItem.java:352) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem$ActionListener.handleEvent (ActionContributionItem.java:47) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java:75) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.notifyListeners(Widget.java:637) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runDeferredEvents(Display.java:1420) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1208) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:755) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:738) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run (InternalBootLoader.java:777) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:319) at EclipseRuntimeLauncher.main(EclipseRuntimeLauncher.java:14) Fixed. We were generating parameters for the ___run() method in the evaluation source based on the type name of local variable values, instead of the type name of the local variable itself.
In this case, a local variable was declared as an Enumeration but its value was an anonymous inner class instance. Please verify. Still getting the same stack trace if the "e" variable is selected in the variables view. This was caused by an unrelated problem in the EvaluationSourceGenerator.getTypeFromProject() method. We ask for a java element from the project and then get the type from the returned object by checking what the returned object is an instanceof (unfortunately). We were missing a case.
I also added NPE protection to this method which should have been there before. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Breakpoint on line 58 Use source in bug 12452. In the variables view detail pane, inspect "InnerAnon.this.description"
Fixed. We were generating parameters for the ___run() method in the evaluation source based on the type name of local variable values, instead of the type name of the local variable itself.
In this case, a local variable was declared as an Enumeration but its value was an anonymous inner class instance. Please verify. Still getting the same stack trace if the "e" variable is selected in the variables view. This was caused by an unrelated problem in the EvaluationSourceGenerator.getTypeFromProject() method. We ask for a java element from the project and then get the type from the returned object by checking what the returned object is an instanceof (unfortunately). We were missing a case.
I also added NPE protection to this method which should have been there before. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.

The stack trace provided from Nils is a bug but I believe that it is not the reason that the snippet evaluation is failing. "Launch configuration does not exist" debug exception is occurring after the snippet VM has already shutdown (incorrectly). This is the part we are working to understand.
I figured out the problem: spaces in the Project names!! What tipped me off is your suggestion to get the JRE out of the "Program Files" directory. That solved the problem for an empty workspace where "test" was the only project, but in my normal workspace it seemed to work in some projects, but not others. Removing the space solved the problem. Getting rid of spaces everywhere is not an option, as we can not change all the project names, and besides all other debugging works fine. Also when normally installing the JRE it always suggests "Program Files". At this point it should be easy to fix though ;-) -Leon This is great...I thought the two problems where unrelated!
We use a URLClassLoader to load the class that we use for the snippet editor evaluations. We are passing it urls that contains spaces. For the rt.jar, I I thought, but it turns out for the referenced projects as well. This does not work (obviously!). I need to properly encode the Strings to create the URLs...or anybody else who wants to tackle the problem in ScrapbookMain. ;-)
Until that time: to use the scrapbook do not use a JRE/JDK that has spaces in the path or reference any projects that have spaces in the name, or use in an Eclipse install that has spaces in its path. i have tested this and it was also the case at my place, i had one project that didn't have a space in the name and didn't have any references to other projects and also the rt.jar of the jdk had no spaces in it. But it of the 25 jars, besides the rt.jar, one jar that was included had a space in his path. Removed it and it did work.
A fix has been released into the HEAD stream and will be part of the next integration build. Fixed. See bug 14360. please verify (darinW) Verified

Bug.Summery: Window > Decorators in wrong menu for what it does...
Bug.WithStack:
It would make more sense to move the Decorators menu item to the Workbench menu. Since it applies to all windows in the workbench, not just the current window. The Window menu is usually reserved for actions that apply to the current window only. Decorators should have their own preference page, under the Workbench page. This may require a couple more steps than using a menu, but it also allows for more explanation, and is more consistent with other prefs. My feeling is that these aren't toggled often enough to warrant a separate menu.
We should avoid the term "decorator" in the UI. I suggest using "label decorations" instead.
Obsolete. Decorators moved to a PreferencePage.

Bug.Summery: Workspace runnable not run correctly
Bug.WithStack:
In JavaBreakpoint#removeFromTarget, a workspace runnable is created and run directly - it should call #run(IWorkspaceRunnable) rather than invoking the runnable directly.
Check all runnables in breakpoints for same bug. Fixed and checked that this was the only oversight in the breakpoint hierarchy. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
In JavaBreakpoint#removeFromTarget, a workspace runnable is created and run directly - it should call #run(IWorkspaceRunnable) rather than invoking the runnable directly.
Check all runnables in breakpoints for same bug. Fixed and checked that this was the only oversight in the breakpoint hierarchy. Please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Error in .classpath for Photon
Bug.WithStack:
In version 2.033 of the org.eclipse.swt project, copying the contents of .classpath_photon to .classpath in Eclipse results in some compile errors. The problem appears to be there are some widget classes defined in both Eclipse SWT/emulated and Eclipse SWT/photon. When I remove the "emulated" element from the .classpath, I get no errors.
Here's the classpath that did not work for me: <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT/photon"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT/emulated"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT/common"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT/common_j2se"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT PI/photon"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT PI/common_j2se"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT Accessibility/emulated"/> <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT Accessibility/common"/>
When I remove the following line, the project compiles without error: <classpathentry kind="src" path="Eclipse SWT/emulated"/> The emulated source folder is necessary. Tree, TreeItem, Table, TableItem, CoolBar, CoolItem are emulated widgets on Photon. TabFolder and TabItem are not. The problem is that we can not add single files to the classpath on Eclipse. Only folders are allowed.
To fix this problem, we need to restruture the emulated source folder. The emulated source folder has been restrutured. This is fixed in the latest (>20020510).

Bug.Summery: Search dialog opens slowly when java file is selected

Bug.WithStack:
If you are in the Java Perspective with class org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.parser.Parser selected when you hit Ctrl H it can take several seconds to open (as long as 6 seconds).
There should be a busy cursor for opening this dialog. As well when I benched the opening of the dialog with the OptimizeIt profiler I found that initializing the selection (JavaSearchPage.initSelections() took 52.8% of the time to open the dialog. Did you dig into the method? I don't think JavaSearchPage.initSelections() took the time but the JavaModel to do the code resolve. ==> it depends on what's selected. Could you provide the selection because when I tried it it was fast. Maybe there's a bug in the Java Model for the type/code you selected.
It was fast when tired it as well.
One difference between Tod's and Dani's workspace could be that Tod has a full source workspace.
I also suspect that code resolve is expensive. Showing a busy cursor when bringing up this dialog is fair. Dani did you try this scenario in the full source workspace? I tested this in the full workspace scenario (i.e. whole Eclipse as source) against build F1.

All tests opened the Java Search page immediately with the right values filled in.
Maybe there was a problem in earlier builds or the Lotus Notes was using most of the CPU (that sometimes happens to me).

Bug.Summery: Cannot start Eclipse
Bug.WithStack:
build 2002-03-21 on Linux/Motif.
Steve had a problem where his workspace would hang after displaying the spash screen. After debugging it, it was determined that all plugin activation code had finished but then it was hanging. A guess was that it was restoring the workbench state. After deleting the workbench.xml file the workspace started up with no problems.
Will attach his workbench.xml file which prevented startup of his workspace. Created attachment 535 workbench.xml I've encountered the same problem. DJ and I tried commenting out parts of the workbench.xml file to try to isolate the problem.
- if we comment out the entire file (i.e. change <workbench version="0.046"> to <!-- workbench version="0.046"> and change the matching close tag) the workspace comes up
- if we comment out everything between the workbench tags (i.e. change <mruList> to <!-- mruList> and <perspHistory> to <!-- perspHistory> and change the matching close tags) the workspace still doesn't come up Created attachment 625 workbench.xml Created attachment 650 javacore file (dumped manually when Eclipse froze) Looks like the problem with running the event loop when no window restored. Please verify.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 13985 *** "Looks like the problem with running the event loop when no window restored. Please verify."
There should be no problem with running an event loop when no window is created in pure SWT code. *** Bug 15280 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: Wrong objects received by IObjectActionDelegate
Bug.WithStack:
This bug probably doesn't belong here, but since it happens with the Java Packages view and I can't see how it would for the Navigator, this seemed like the best place to start. I defined an objectContribution in my plugin.xml with the objectClass set to org.eclipse.core.resources.IResource and adaptable to true. As expected, my action is available from the Java Packages view. However, when my action receives selectionChanged(IAction action, ISelection selection), the selection actually contains IJavaElements. This was unexpected since I specifically requested a contribution for objects of type IResource. I can certainly adapt the objects myself back to IResources, but that seems wasteful since presumably someone else had already done that work already. Moving one layer down to Platform UI I have just tried this in build 20020409 and I get Resources back from an action that defined the following way
<!-- ************** POPUP ACTIONS ******************* --> <extension point="org.eclipse.ui.popupMenus"> <objectContribution objectClass="org.eclipse.core.resources.IResource" id="org.eclipse.ui.actioncontributiontest.ResourceContributions" adaptable = "true"> <action label="Resource Action" class="org.eclipse.ui.actioncontributiontest.ResourceAction" menubarPath="org.eclipse.ui.OpenFileAction" id="resource action"> </action> </objectContribution> </extension>
How are you defining your action? You should be getting Resources back when your selection changed in the JavaPackages View. I defined my action essentially just like yours. However, I've have since moved up to the 4/11 Integration Build and cannot reproduce the problem. So either it was fixed since I originally noted this, or I was just seeing things before. Marking as Works for me

Bug.Summery: Switching working sets should preserved expanded state

Bug.Summery: problem doing cvs checkout without case overlap
Bug.WithStack:
When I do a cvs checkout from a repository that has directory names that clash in the case insensitive windows world the checkout fails. For example, I am checking out on a Windows 2000 machine. The cvs server is unix and has two peer directories, one named "EXAMPLE" and the other named "example". When the second directory is reached in the checkout the error message is displayed:
Problems encountered performing checkout Reason: Problem creating folder: A resource exists with a different case: $PATH . Perform refresh from local
At this point the checkout halts. I am not sure of the best way to handle the naming conflict, but the checkout should probably continue for items that do not conflict. There is no good way for us to handle the name conflict: on Win boxes you can't have siblings that differ only by case.
Continuing with the checkout would be better.
Priority to fix that is low since clearly your project's not going be worth a dang until you resolve the name conflict. Marking post 2.0 for the "continue with load" fix. This was fixed in 2.0 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Contributing action sets from plugin fragments
Bug.WithStack:
Build: 20020328
I attempted to contribute an action set to the UI plugin. The class for the action delegate was found, but the icons were not. I believe this is due to the fact that WorkbenchImages.getImageDescriptorFromExtension(...) does not search plugin fragments for icons. This means that translators cannot provide translated icons. It also means that product developers cannot override the default icons with icons of their own. This bug is stopping me from packaging the editor management view I wrote for Bug 10941.
This bug makes plugin fragments unusable for contributions that contain icons. DJ, what's the right way to look up resources including fragments again? Should use IPluginDescriptor.find(...).
yes, IPluginDescriptor.find or Plugin.find should work. Plugin.find should not be used as that causes plugin activation. Knut to wrap up on Monday - assuming it is as simple as the proposed fix that I sent NE. To ensure exactly the old behavior in error cases we now fall back to the old code when IPluginDescriptor.find could not find the requested image.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: 20020328
I attempted to contribute an action set to the UI plugin. The class for the action delegate was found, but the icons were not. I believe this is due to the fact that WorkbenchImages.getImageDescriptorFromExtension(...) does not search plugin fragments for icons. This means that translators cannot provide translated icons. It also means that product developers cannot override the default icons with icons of their own. This bug is stopping me from packaging the editor management view I wrote for Bug 10941.
This bug makes plugin fragments unusable for contributions that contain icons. DJ, what's the right way to look up resources including fragments again? Should use IPluginDescriptor.find(...).
yes, IPluginDescriptor.find or Plugin.find should work. Plugin.find should not be used as that causes plugin activation. Knut to wrap up on Monday - assuming it is as simple as the proposed fix that I sent NE. To ensure exactly the old behavior in error cases we now fall back to the old code when IPluginDescriptor.find could not find the requested image.

Bug.Summery: NPE out of the CompletionEngine
Bug.WithStack:
I believe there is a bug in the org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.CompletionEngine. When I am code assisting in the detail pane of the variables view for a class such as "Sample$1 $InnerClass" I get the following NPE.
I believe the completion engine should be using the topLevelType instead of the type at line 598 to generate the typeDeclaration.
NPE: java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.codeassist.CompletionEngine.complete (CompletionEngine.java:605) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.SourceType.codeComplete (SourceType.java:68) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.debug.ui.display.DetailsCompletionProcessor.computeComp letionProposals(DetailsCompletionProcessor.java:64) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.ContentAssistant.computeCompletionProposals (ContentAssistant.java:1197) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.CompletionProposalPopup.computeProposals (CompletionProposalPopup.java:103) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.CompletionProposalPopup.access$3 (CompletionProposalPopup.java:102) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.CompletionProposalPopup$1.run (CompletionProposalPopup.java:71) at org.eclipse.swt.custom.BusyIndicator.showWhile(BusyIndicator.java:56) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.CompletionProposalPopup.showProposals (CompletionProposalPopup.java:66) at org.eclipse.jface.text.contentassist.ContentAssistant$2.run (ContentAssistant.java:265) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:29) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages (Synchronizer.java:93) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:1397) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:1211) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:755) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:738) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run (InternalBootLoader.java:777) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:319) at EclipseRuntimeLauncher.main(EclipseRuntimeLauncher.java:14) I can not reproduce this problem. Could you give me a more accurate test case ? Created attachment 543 Sample.java Test Case (using latest code in HEAD on dev.eclipse.org): Use the attached source (Sample.java), breakpoint on line 32. Debug, hit breakpoint Go to the variables view showing the detail pane Select the "this" variable Code assist in the detail pane (popup menu or ctrl-space)
There is an error in my code. I correct it and now NPE does not occur.
But with this test case no completion proposal are possible because the completion is on the member type Sample.InnerClass and this type does not exist.
Fixed. Doing a code completion in the Java Editor at line 36 with "this." gives the following completions: innerClassVar1 innerClassIVar1 innerMethod1(String innerArg1) <<all the methods inherited from Object>>
Doing it with the "this" variable selected in the variables view with "this." entered in the detail pane we get no completions
why is this different? In DisplayCompletionProcessor#getType you use IType#getType. This method can give a handle on member type, but not local type and not anonymous type. In fact it is not possible to create a handle on local or anonymous.
DisplayCompletionProcessor ------------------------------------------------------ protected IType getType( ... ) throws DebugException {
...
try {
...
for (int i = 1; i < typeNames.length; i++) { String innerTypeName= typeNames[i]; try { Integer.parseInt(innerTypeName); continue; //loop over anonymous types } catch (NumberFormatException e) { } type = type.getType(innerTypeName); } } catch (JavaModelException e) { throw new DebugException(e.getStatus()); }
return type; } ------------------------------------------------------ The enclosing type of the completion is the local type Sample$1$InnerClass. But in this algorithm the result is a handle on member type Sample$InnerClass and this member type does not exist. That's why there is no completion.

why is this different? In DisplayCompletionProcessor#getType you use IType#getType. This method can give a handle on member type, but not local type and not anonymous type. In fact it is not possible to create a handle on local or anonymous.

Bug.Summery: inconsistency in naming of attributes
Bug.WithStack:
I found a minor "bug" which I think must be corrected to get consistency in the naming of attributes when they contain the same data. I found the inconsistency in the following tags:
<launchConfigurationTypeImage> <launchConfigurationTab>
Where configTypeID in <launchConfigurationTypeImage> referes to antoher tag and where type in <launchConfigurationTab> also referes to another tag. Joe Szurszewski told me (look at my post in the newsgroup) that <launchConfigurationTabGroups> also suffers from the same attribute name inconsistency. So please make consistency in the naming of attributes when they contain the same data. Darin, making this fix is going to break existing launch config delegates. When do you want to do it? Defer this problem as it involves breaking other launch configuration implementors, and this would be a bad thing to do just before 2.0 goes out. Reopening for moving since it does not belong to PDE Core. The "launchConfigurationTab" extension point no longer exists in 2.0 - it was replaced with "launchConfigurationTabGroups". I suggest to make the stadard tag be "type" (simpler). For backwards compatibility, we will still support "configTypeID".
marking as 2.1 candidate Fixed. If the "configTypeID" attribute is not present, we look for "type". please verify, Joe. Verified.

Bug.Summery: [Contributions] Request ability to set action visibility
Bug.WithStack:
Currently IAction has a setEnabled() method which allows me to programmatically control the enablement of an Action rather than relying on the XML to determine this. However, there is no setVisible() type method to programmatically control visibility as an alternative to the XML approach.
I looked at the actionExpressions document as it relates to visibility, but it doesn't really help in all cases. Specifically, since I'm dealing with the Java Packages view, it's quite conceivable that the objectState attributes which JDT provides for their elements are insufficient and unrelated to the specific information needed for my particular plugin to make visibility of my actions work as desired. And as IActionFilters are provided by the view itself, they don't seem to be the answer either. If you require this support in the 2.0 version of eclipse please reopen this defect. Reopen to investigate One reason why there is no support for this is because it will confuse the user when a menu item "disapears" on them. Until your plugin is loaded, the platform would show your action in the menu and the user would see it. Then the user does something in the UI (not having to do with your action) that causes your plugin to be loaded. Now when the user looks in the menu, your action would be gone (because your delegate was given the chance to update the action when the plugin was loaded).
Did you have any ideas how you envisioned this to work? At the moment, I'm not sure this is something we want to add API for. I originally opened this request because I was attempting to support the following: our plugin supports various debugging options (ie, via - debug "file:d:\.options") which includes the addition of several actions to menus. If it were my own view, I could construct a context menu to include or not include these actions based on the option settings. However, the menu I needed to affect was in the Package Explorer view. As it stands, the control over visibility via xml is too limited to address this need and hence my additional menu choices are always visible whether debug options have been specified or not. I was merely seeking a programmatic equivalent to what could be done in a limited way via the xml. And I noted that enablement was already controllable both with xml and programmatically, so this seemed like a symmetrical request. I think I understand your point about the possible confusion for the user, but honestly it's no less confusing than what already occurs for enablement in my opinion. As it stands now, actions will initially appear enabled and it's not until the user attempts to access them that it is determined they are not applicable. So I pick an enabled action, it tells me I can't do that right now, and if I go right back to the menu, it's now disabled. Personally, that strikes me as confusing. And as a result of that innocent action, I've now activated that action's plugin and who knows what the bottom line result of the plugin being activated is (ie, builders, resource change listeners, etc, etc), all of which could have been averted if the menu choice was simply not there or disabled. Ultimately I would like to be able to have some small snippet of code that could be executed to determine visibility and/or enablement but doesn't result in full blown plugin activation (no small request, I understand). But for now, all I was looking for was a visibility equivalent to IAction.setEnabled().
Reassigning to Platform-UI-Inbox (I left IBM 18 months ago..) Moving Dougs bugs Assigning to component owner PW
With menu contributions you can tie your visibility to contexts, object properties, or even action sets. Available as part of the command framework in 3.3.
PW

Bug.Summery: DBCS:Search function for online Help does not work for DBCS.

Lines.Line: 1) Pick a string from translated help that contains hirigana and kanji in it.
2) Search on this string.
- Install driver 20020321 SDK on S.Chinese Win2K.
- under org.eclipse.platform.doc.user,replace US-English doc.zip with the
S.Chinese doc.zip from the NL fragment.
- From the tool bar, select the search function( the flash light), select
"Help search" tab, paste a DBCS string you have copy from the S. Chinese
online help, press Search button.
==> you get "zero" findings even though the string does exist in the
online help.
There probably was no Analyzer plugged in for the Chinese. Help defaulted to
using Lucene Standard Analyzer that is not appropriate for DBCS.

Bug.WithStack:
The search function for Online Help cannot search DBCS string. The search function return "zero" findings even though the string does exist in the online Help. Tested with stable driver 20020321 on S.Chinese Win2K.
- Install driver 20020321 SDK on S.Chinese Win2K. - under org.eclipse.platform.doc.user,replace US-English doc.zip with the S.Chinese doc.zip from the NL fragment. - From the tool bar, select the search function( the flash light), select "Help search" tab, paste a DBCS string you have copy from the S. Chinese online help, press Search button. ==> you get "zero" findings even though the string does exist in the online help. There probably was no Analyzer plugged in for the Chinese. Help defaulted to using Lucene Standard Analyzer that is not appropriate for DBCS.
I have just implemented an Analyzer that properly extracts words in DBCS languages using java.text.BreakIterator. This Analyzer is now the default one to be used when no dedicated analyzer for the language is plugged in.
The code should appear in the next Nightly build (20020417 or later). 20020416 integration buld will not yet include these changes.
Cam, can you wait for a driver and verify that search works for you? Reopen the defect if you get no hits. Try search with build 20020425. Reopen bug as search still does not work. We get no search hit. Have you tested with 20020425 integration or nightly build? I get search hits using 20020425 integration builds. The NL is broken in the 20020425 nightly build, but is working again in the latest code and should be fine in the next integration build 20020430.
We have tried with build 502 on all the double byte languages. Everything except Japanese appears to be fine so far. The Japanese problem arises when the search string is a mix of Hirigana and Kanji. The result is that the string is found, but then it also highlights the hirigana character and the kanji (if they occur separately) all over the place.
To replicate this: 1) Pick a string from translated help that contains hirigana and kanji in it. 2) Search on this string.
I will attach a screenshot of an example run on our machines. Created attachment 769 Hirigana and Kanji search string This is good news for us and hopefully we can fix the highlighting problem in a future release. A good Japanese langugage analyzer would also fix the problem. Note that the lang analyzers are pluggable and can be contributed at a later time. Highlighting is done in the browser, using JavaScript, and it is not as precise as we would like to eventually achieve. The search query is parsed into tokens by the language analyzer used during indexing, and then each word is matched against the text displayed in the browser. So, all the substrings in the text that match any of the input tokens will be highlighted and I think this is the behavior that you are seeing.
I will mark this bug as fixed. The Default analyzer that uses java.text package converts the three letters query (from your screen shot) to two words. One word is just the first Hirigana character, and the second word consist of the two Kanji characters. If this is not correct (such words do not exist), we cannot fix it as the code is part of the java runtime.
If this is correct, but in this particular case the query should be treated as one word, or the Hirigana character should be omitted from search (removing common prefixes or similar operations), a specific analyzer for Japanese can be plugged in. We only provide a basic one that converts this query to two words as described above.

Bug.Summery: Single click launching doesn't work if the active editor isn't selected
Bug.WithStack:
For single click launching to launch the active editor, the editor must have focus. This can be improved.
If the currently selected item (a breakpoint, for instance) cannot be launched, the launcher can ask the currently active IWorkbenchPage for the active editor. From there the code is the same as the case where the editor has focus. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
For single click launching to launch the active editor, the editor must have focus. This can be improved.
If the currently selected item (a breakpoint, for instance) cannot be launched, the launcher can ask the currently active IWorkbenchPage for the active editor. From there the code is the same as the case where the editor has focus. Fixed. Please verify. Verified.

Bug.Summery: File selection dialog for choosing external file editor freezes (Linux)
Bug.WithStack:
Overview: The file selector dialog box for choosing an external file editor freezes under Linux.
Details: I was attempting to add gvim as an editor for .java files. Workbench->Preferences->Workbench->File Editors Under "File types" I click on ".java", then under "Associated editors" I click on "Add". This brings up an "Editor Selection" dialog box. I click "External Programs", then "Browse". This brings up a file selection box displaying the contents of my home directory. This last box does not respond to any mouse clicks or keystrokes; I have to kill the whole application.
Build info: Red Hat 7.1, Eclipse SDK 20020321 (stable). This is a known problem on the GTK drop. Is that what you are running?
I think so: eclipse-SDK-20020321-linux-gtk1x.zip .
Is there any workaround, or is it something that can/will be fixed for the next stable release?
I'm sorry if this is a redundant bug report. I searched on "file editor" and didn't find it. That's the GTK1.x version (which is all you can currently get). If you don't care which version you are running and need to get going right away, you should try the Motif one. It is much more stable.
You'll have to wait for the GTK2 version (which is currently being worked on full time by several developers) to see a fix on GTK. It shouldn't be too much longer.
Boris: We need to make sure that this bug is not in the GTK2 version. It seems to be the most common issue. Okay, I will try the Motif version for now, and await the GTK2 version.
Thank you. Fixed. The fix is also backported to the 1.2 stream.

Bug.Summery: Manually adding to .cvsignore does not clear task for new resources
Bug.WithStack:
When you create a new file for a project under CVS control you get a task telling you the file is not ignored or added (cool!).
Incidentally, this works great for changing a Java project to have src/bin, because you see right away that /bin needs to be dealt with.
If you go the navigator and select /bin and "Add to .cvsignore", the task isn't removed. Curiously, the task *is* removed if you pick the same thing from Autofix. Fixed Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When you create a new file for a project under CVS control you get a task telling you the file is not ignored or added (cool!).
Incidentally, this works great for changing a Java project to have src/bin, because you see right away that /bin needs to be dealt with.
If you go the navigator and select /bin and "Add to .cvsignore", the task isn't removed. Curiously, the task *is* removed if you pick the same thing from Autofix. Fixed Verified.

Bug.Summery: An Error occured during the search operation
Bug.WithStack:
I was searching for some text within eclipse and I got the following message:
An Error occured during the search operation. Reason: File not found E:\x.MF
I am not sure if that file exists or not but it seems to me that search should have better error handling I have noticed before that it will stop searching if one of the files it starts to parse is out of synch with eclipse. Search should give me the option to stop or ignore that file it should not just stop. This is text search, not Java search Yeah text search, that's right. I am never sure which component or product to file bugs under. Is it under the right one. Moving to Platform/UI for comment as they implement text searching. Dealing with out of sync resources is a general problem - not specific to search. Adding DJ to the CC list what is possible for 2.0 search should report a multi status with failures.
Fixed. General support from core would be nice (e.g. status aware operations) Available in builds > 20020508
As a note, the auto-refresh plugin is available from the Core team web page off http://www.eclipse.org.
This will synchronize resources in the workspace with the resources in the file system, in a background task.
Potential integration into Core is a post-2.0 possibility.

Bug.Summery: Large amounts of traces in log after debugging in J9
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020328
After an afternoon of debugging with this build and J9, my log file had literally hundreds of errors logged in it. They all seem to be related to the debugger. I was doing fairly typical UI work, modifying code then testing by opening/closing a preference page. I noticed that HCR was failing in some cases, such as on method creations and method visibility changes, but other than that it seemed to be working fine. I will attach the log file. Created attachment 536 Log file showing stack traces Note that most of the bugs are "stack frame unavailable", but there are also some Internal errors and NullPointerExceptions toward the bottom of the log. Created attachment 539 Trimmed log Bug 12591 addressed the "Variable information unavailable..." error. Most (all?) of these problems have been addressed in other bug reports.
In the future, please file one bug report per bug and include steps to reproduce.

Bug.Summery: ClassNotLoaded JDI exception during conditional breakpoint

Lines.Line: 1. New workbench
2. Import all plugins using the plugin import wizard (copy all plugins into the
workspace)
3. Add a breakpoint to org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Object) line 731.
4. Set the following conditional on the breakpoint
System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis())
5. Debug using the Run-time workbench launcher
6. An error dialog will pop up claiming to have compilation problems
*** Bug 12842 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
This is caused by a bug in our JDI implementation around multiple class loaders.

Bug.WithStack:
Build: 20020402
Follow these steps:
1. New workbench 2. Import all plugins using the plugin import wizard (copy all plugins into the workspace) 3. Add a breakpoint to org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Object) line 731. 4. Set the following conditional on the breakpoint System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis()) 5. Debug using the Run-time workbench launcher 6. An error dialog will pop up claiming to have compilation problems *** Bug 12842 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is caused by a bug in our JDI implementation around multiple class loaders.
If we try to create a ReferenceTypeImpl (the JDI representation of a class) for a local type (a type in a method) that has a different classloader than the class loader used by the enclosing type of the method, our implementation throws an exception.
Different classloaders can load a class with the same fully qualified name, so when we ask the VM for a ReferenceType with a given signature it actually returns a collection of types. The old implementation looked for a type whose classloader matched the class loader of the enclosing type of the method.
The fix is to make a second pass if the first pass finds no such type. In the second pass, we ask the enclosing method's classloader to get all visible types (it's really unfortunate, but this is the ONLY thing that a classloader can do with the JDWP spec) and we then check if one of the returned types is in the visible types.
Whichever type is visible to the enclosing type's class loader is the type that appears in local methods in the enclosing type.
Fixed. Please verify. Verified. We later refactored our local variable name lookup to get the reference type name directly from local variables instead of getting the type and asking the type for the name. Without the call to getType(), we no longer make a JDWP request when building local variables.
This code was released with the refactoring from Bug 12997 *** Bug 15158 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 14950 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: 20020402
Follow these steps:
1. New workbench 2. Import all plugins using the plugin import wizard (copy all plugins into the workspace) 3. Add a breakpoint to org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Object) line 731. 4. Set the following conditional on the breakpoint System.out.println(System.currentTimeMillis()) 5. Debug using the Run-time workbench launcher 6. An error dialog will pop up claiming to have compilation problems *** Bug 12842 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** This is caused by a bug in our JDI implementation around multiple class loaders.
If we try to create a ReferenceTypeImpl (the JDI representation of a class) for a local type (a type in a method) that has a different classloader than the class loader used by the enclosing type of the method, our implementation throws an exception.
Different classloaders can load a class with the same fully qualified name, so when we ask the VM for a ReferenceType with a given signature it actually returns a collection of types. The old implementation looked for a type whose classloader matched the class loader of the enclosing type of the method.
The fix is to make a second pass if the first pass finds no such type. In the second pass, we ask the enclosing method's classloader to get all visible types (it's really unfortunate, but this is the ONLY thing that a classloader can do with the JDWP spec) and we then check if one of the returned types is in the visible types.
Whichever type is visible to the enclosing type's class loader is the type that appears in local methods in the enclosing type.
Fixed. Please verify. Verified. We later refactored our local variable name lookup to get the reference type name directly from local variables instead of getting the type and asking the type for the name. Without the call to getType(), we no longer make a JDWP request when building local variables.
This code was released with the refactoring from Bug 12997 *** Bug 15158 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** *** Bug 14950 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: 1GTDNR0: Installing plugins from remote locations hangs WSDD and network stack
Bug.WithStack:
Problem Description: On some of our machines, WSDD will hang when trying to add any plugin from an internet location (the progress bar never shows any progress). The only way to stop WSDD at this point, is to kill it from the task manager. Also, when WSDD hangs, the entire network stack on the host machine fails (can not ping or use browsers). Network connectivity returns when WSDD is killed by the task manager. This is strange as it happens every time on about one third of our machines.
Reinstalling WSDD, using a new workspace, or installing a slightly different version of WSDD does not fix the problem.
If we try to add a plugin from the CD, it works fine.
The hang occurs after the follow sequence of actions: Help->Device Developer Updates->Add->(select any predefined internet location)-> Next I did not experience any hang. I did notice that trying cancel the update seems to have no effect. It continues with the update after clicking on cancel. Basically the cancel button has no effect.
is this update? Yes, this is using the update feature. Can you please specify which eclipse build you are running? This is based on the 1.0 eclipse. (WSDD 4.0 GM) OK, we will need a bit of help with this one.
* you said the hang happens "on some of our machines" ... what are these machines running (OS + any fixpacks, jdk level, etc)
* is there a particilar site/ specific download you can points us at that is causing this
* any specific steps to reproduce please update status or close Close this one. Thanks. Close

Bug.Summery: Screenshots
Bug.WithStack:
Maybe it's a good idea to provide some screenshots of Eclipse on your site. This is standard practice in the OSS world, and could attract a lot of extra users.
I've prepared some screenshots, so that could be a start. Mail me with instructions on how to send them to you.
Cheers, tomK I think this is important too.
The shots should be from all the different platforms and some variation in the perspectives of course. Created attachment 1888 Eclipse 2.0 Motif running on Slackware Linux. Created attachment 1892 JDT in action: "for" template completion in Java editor Created attachment 1893 JDT in action: console "fast view" in Java browsing perspective I very agree with you. The first thing I search when I gone on www.eclipse.org was some screenshots. I have some friends which never download Eclipse because they prefer to see what they will have before to download and install it.
Every free software has a web site with screenshots, except Eclipse. It will be a very good publicity for the project if the link is on the home page. Well, screenshots are in the "New and worth... features" :-) I agree. There should be a screenshots section. *** Bug 90821 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** the screenshot website is already there (rudimentary as it is), it's just not linked anywhere http://www.eclipse.org/screenshots/ Those are awful, and old. I think it's really bad that there're no screenshots on the website. Is it on any sort of plan to put some up? Wayne, can we look into getting some screenshots/screencasts up for Phoenix 1.1? Can do. It would be interesting to get the community to take some screenshots that represent Eclipse In Action on various platforms. We could also define categories - JDT, Ant, Webtools, etc. Users could post their screenshots here, in this bug, and we could publish the best ones. If we go this route, would need some posting guidelines (ie, plugin restrictions, code on the screenshot, etc).
Just a suggestion..
D. Looking at screenshots people have sent me over the years, I'd be very skeptical the quality would be good enough on community supplied screenshots. It's just hard to get consistently good screenshots and everybody has a different idea of what "good" means. Ask anybody who's worked on a multi-author book. Where are the screenshots in CVS? I don't believe they're in CVS.
http://www.eclipse.org/screenshots/ How do we feel about replacing screen shots with screen cams?
I have a bunch of screen cams at http://www.eclipse.org/callisto/java.php.
Or do we really want screen shots? Four is not what I'd call 'a bunch'. Screencasts are nice but they're harder to make than screenshots. Given that the screenshots (like http://www.eclipse.org/screenshots/fullscreenXP/JavaPerspective.gif) can't be kept up to date, why do you think screencasts would? Screencasts require users to click and wait to showcase the exciting stuff. Consider:
http://www.mozilla.com/thunderbird/ http://kde.org/ -> screenshots to the left After much stalling, I have updated the screenshots page.
Please see http://www.eclipse.org/screenshots
Since I only have access to Windows XP and Linux, the screenshots are on those platforms only. I may replace some of the Win XP shots with some GTK ones (in addition to the KDE ones). I added a couple that weren't previously there, including "Compare with Local History", "Java Debugging", and "Visual Editor".
I'd love it if somebody could contribute some images for other platforms, especially the Mac. (In reply to comment #8) > the screenshot website is already there (rudimentary as it is), it's just not > linked anywhere
Any thoughts on where they should be linked from?
The KDE ones look funny, as if they were improperly scaled.
You need a lab with each major platform represented so you can do stuff like this consistently, rather than relying on random contributions. (In reply to comment #22) > The KDE ones look funny, as if they were improperly scaled.
Agreed. I wanted to put something there that wasn't Windows XP. This was the best that I could do with what I have available. I'll see if I can get something better from my Fedora installation.
> You need a lab with each major platform represented so you can do stuff like > this consistently, rather than relying on random contributions.
Actually, I'm looking for contributions of a less random kind. If I can't manage to get anybody to volunteer some good screen shots, I'll go bother Kim, Ward, or some other Mac-o-phile. In the meantime, I'll get some better Linux shots myself.
I'm marking this bug as fixed since I think the original requirement has been satisfied. I will continue to look for and add new screen shots on an ongoing basis. Created attachment 51669 Mac screenshot showing AJDT
Wayne, Here is a Mac screenshot, showing an aspect being editing with AJDT, the AspectJ Development Tools Did you want a Windows Vista screenshot? There's an old one at: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=28571 (In reply to comment #26) > Did you want a Windows Vista screenshot? > There's an old one at: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=28571 >
Added. Thanks. (In reply to comment #25) > Created an attachment (id=51669) [edit] > Mac screenshot showing AJDT > > Wayne, > Here is a Mac screenshot, showing an aspect being editing with AJDT, the > AspectJ Development Tools >
Added. Thanks. Moving to Community/Website

Bug.Summery: untouched files are marked as outgoing changes

Lines.Line: 1) Do 'Replace All' from repositories for all source projects
2) Verify that the projects don't appear to be changed (no '>' symbol)
3) Restart workbench
4) Verify that all source projects now have the '>' symbol.

Bug.WithStack:
I-20020402 on w2k:
A lot of files in the workspace which were never touched are marked as outgoing changes. Interestingly, this doesn't happen on Linux-Motif. Just a thought. We had a daylight savings change yesterday in Switzerland and I remember that we had similar problems with this on Windows earlier. Here's the report about the Daylight Savings Time problem. Bug 5337. Unfortuanatly I don't think that there's anything we can do about it. we had a problem with our CVS server in ZRH. It was going one hour ahead in addition to the daylight saving time. Fixing this doesn't seem to help.
1) Do 'Replace All' from repositories for all source projects 2) Verify that the projects don't appear to be changed (no '>' symbol) 3) Restart workbench 4) Verify that all source projects now have the '>' symbol.
Note that this behaviour is specific to I-20020402. In I-20020328 replacing projects works as expected.
Note: If I remove a project completely and add it back to workspace again, things work normally again. I'm seeing a lot of this, on WinXP with build 20020404. I have a lot of files showing up as outgoing changes or conflicts when they have not been modified locally. It does not seem to have anything to do with daylight savings, since my client machine has not switched over yet (it will tonight). The priority should be bumped up.
Note that I have a workspace which has been around for a few builds. It was created with build 20020328 on March 28th.
Tried doing a refresh local on the project and re-syncing. It did not fix the problem. I have the same problem on WinNT with NTFS. I can bring the local workspace in synch but after I exit and restart everything is messed up. I'd also like this to get a higher prio. I don't use build 20020402 and 20020404 because it's pain to re-synch all my project after each re-start.

Bug.Summery: Plugin Import: Yes/No to all checkbox removed
Bug.WithStack: 20020328 The reason to take a checkbox instead of the 'Yes to All' was that there were complaints wanting also a 'No to All' button. When setting up a new workspace, a way is to first get all projects you want in source from cvs, then use the plugin importer to import all others. You don't have to care about deselecting all already existing, as you can say, No to all when asked for overwriting. Button 'No to All' has been added in 0402 build. The reason the checkbox has been removed was because it introduced a mode, whereby the same buttons (Yes and No) did different things depending on the state of the checkbox. Modes are generally regarded as something to be avoided in user interface design. I have confirmed this with usability leads in IBM. Adding explicit 'Yes to All' and 'No to All' buttons makes the button array longer, but each button does exactly what its label says (no modes). We found a a dialog in CoolEdit2000 that also has the "Yes/Yes to All/No/No to All/Cancel" button array.
Bug.WithOutStack: 20020328 The reason to take a checkbox instead of the 'Yes to All' was that there were complaints wanting also a 'No to All' button. When setting up a new workspace, a way is to first get all projects you want in source from cvs, then use the plugin importer to import all others. You don't have to care about deselecting all already existing, as you can say, No to all when asked for overwriting. Button 'No to All' has been added in 0402 build. The reason the checkbox has been removed was because it introduced a mode, whereby the same buttons (Yes and No) did different things depending on the state of the checkbox. Modes are generally regarded as something to be avoided in user interface design. I have confirmed this with usability leads in IBM. Adding explicit 'Yes to All' and 'No to All' buttons makes the button array longer, but each button does exactly what its label says (no modes). We found a a dialog in CoolEdit2000 that also has the "Yes/Yes to All/No/No to All/Cancel" button array.

Bug.Summery: org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.javaeditor.CompilationUnitDocumentProvider$ProblemAnnotation when saving java files

Lines.Line: 1) Create a new Java project.
2) Create a new class within the project.
3) Edit the class using the java editor.
4) Add some text to cause a compilation problem (for example: type the
text "private;" inside the class, to cause a compilation problem).
5) Save the file. You get a valid compilation error.
6) Now delete the text you've added.
7) Save the file. You should get a valid compilation now, but instead you get
an exception.

Bug.WithStack:
Using the nightly build from 20020402.
Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a new Java project. 2) Create a new class within the project. 3) Edit the class using the java editor. 4) Add some text to cause a compilation problem (for example: type the text "private;" inside the class, to cause a compilation problem). 5) Save the file. You get a valid compilation error. 6) Now delete the text you've added. 7) Save the file. You should get a valid compilation now, but instead you get an exception.
The exception text will be attached to this report. Created attachment 538 The full exception text (the class-cast exception) seems to work in the 20020404 integration build. Pls reopen if you can reproduce it in an integration build.
To quote the downloads page: Nightly builds are produced every night from whatever has been released into the HEAD stream of the CVS repository. They are completely untested and will almost always have major problems. Many will not work at all. These drops are normally only useful to developers actually working on the Eclipse Project.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Using the nightly build from 20020402.
Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a new Java project. 2) Create a new class within the project. 3) Edit the class using the java editor. 4) Add some text to cause a compilation problem (for example: type the text "private;" inside the class, to cause a compilation problem). 5) Save the file. You get a valid compilation error. 6) Now delete the text you've added. 7) Save the file. You should get a valid compilation now, but instead you get an exception.
The exception text will be attached to this report. Created attachment 538 The full exception text (the class-cast exception) seems to work in the 20020404 integration build. Pls reopen if you can reproduce it in an integration build.
To quote the downloads page: Nightly builds are produced every night from whatever has been released into the HEAD stream of the CVS repository. They are completely untested and will almost always have major problems. Many will not work at all. These drops are normally only useful to developers actually working on the Eclipse Project.

Bug.Summery: Too many problems while reconciling
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020402
When reconciling, some problems may surface which were detected inside a different unit, e.g.
Project1 +- X.java Project2 (prereqs Project1) +- Y.java extends P1/X.java Project3 (prereqs Project2) +- Z.java extends P2/Y.java
When reconciling Project3/Z.java, an error should be detected since its hierarchy needs X.java which isn't visible on Project3's classpath, but this error is only reported against Y.java (directly), and should not be surfaced when reconciling Z.java. Filter added. Fixed DOM Ast CompilationUnitResolver had same bug. Fixed too.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020402
When reconciling, some problems may surface which were detected inside a different unit, e.g.
Project1 +- X.java Project2 (prereqs Project1) +- Y.java extends P1/X.java Project3 (prereqs Project2) +- Z.java extends P2/Y.java
When reconciling Project3/Z.java, an error should be detected since its hierarchy needs X.java which isn't visible on Project3's classpath, but this error is only reported against Y.java (directly), and should not be surfaced when reconciling Z.java. Filter added. Fixed DOM Ast CompilationUnitResolver had same bug. Fixed too.

Bug.Summery: Changes to validateEdit/validateSave
Bug.WithStack:
Original spec: - in the case where there is no validator present, #validateEdit immediately returns Status.OK
Ammended spec: - Status.ERROR will be returned if the file is readonly, regardless of whether or not a validator is registered. Added Jeem to CC for comment on ammended APIs. I would say the same thing a little differently:
- in the case where there is no validator present, validateEdit returns Status.ERROR if the file is readonly, and otherwise Status.OK
Team team should check and approve this change.
Jim's phrasing is correct, and is exactly what we do if there is no provider (equivalent case). Fixed and released.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Original spec: - in the case where there is no validator present, #validateEdit immediately returns Status.OK
Ammended spec: - Status.ERROR will be returned if the file is readonly, regardless of whether or not a validator is registered. Added Jeem to CC for comment on ammended APIs. I would say the same thing a little differently:
- in the case where there is no validator present, validateEdit returns Status.ERROR if the file is readonly, and otherwise Status.OK
Team team should check and approve this change.
Jim's phrasing is correct, and is exactly what we do if there is no provider (equivalent case). Fixed and released.
