Bug.Summery: Invalid Thread Access self hosting using Java Search

Lines.Line: 1) Self host Eclipse
2) Select Java Search
3) Enter the name of a class
4) Hit Search - Invalid Thread Access

Bug.WithStack:
The Java Search causes an Invalid Thread Access when you are self hosting. This will also occur if you use search in a JUnit test or if I run Eclipse using the following options:
eclipse -ws win32 -debug -dev bin
The problem is a call to Display.getCurrent() in the initialization code for the JavaEditorPreferencePage which is called the first time you do a search.
STEPS 1) Self host Eclipse 2) Select Java Search 3) Enter the name of a class 4) Hit Search - Invalid Thread Access
Log: Wed Apr 03 08:57:31 EST 2002 4 org.eclipse.jdt.ui 1 Internal Error java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException: org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Invalid thread access at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:1887) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:1819) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.checkDevice(Display.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.checkDevice(Display.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.getSystemColor(Display.java:965) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.preferences.JavaEditorPreferencePage.initDefaults (JavaEditorPreferencePage.java:209) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.JavaPlugin.initializeDefaultPreferences (JavaPlugin.java:320) at org.eclipse.ui.plugin.AbstractUIPlugin.getPreferenceStore (AbstractUIPlugin.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.preferences.AppearancePreferencePage.showMethodRetur nType(AppearancePreferencePage.java:40) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.viewsupport.StandardJavaUILabelProvider.initMasks (StandardJavaUILabelProvider.java:43) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.viewsupport.StandardJavaUILabelProvider.<init> (StandardJavaUILabelProvider.java:29) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.search.JavaSearchResultLabelProvider.<init> (JavaSearchResultLabelProvider.java:39) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.search.JavaSearchResultCollector.aboutToStart (JavaSearchResultCollector.java:104) at org.eclipse.jdt.core.search.SearchEngine.search (SearchEngine.java:376) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.ui.search.JavaSearchOperation.execute (JavaSearchOperation.java:84) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceModifyOperation$1.run (WorkspaceModifyOperation.java:64) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run (Workspace.java:1343) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.WorkspaceModifyOperation.run (WorkspaceModifyOperation.java:78) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run (ModalContext.java:98) The plugin can be activated in any thread and the plugin activation can result in initialization of the preference store. Therefore preference initialization may not access the Display.
*** Bug 15171 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The illegal thread access can happen whenever getPreferenceStore is called from a non-UI thread (see also 15171). It calls JavaEditorPreferencePage.initDefaults that needs access to the Display to get the system colors.

Bug.WithOutStack:
The Java Search causes an Invalid Thread Access when you are self hosting. This will also occur if you use search in a JUnit test or if I run Eclipse using the following options:
eclipse -ws win32 -debug -dev bin
The problem is a call to Display.getCurrent() in the initialization code for the JavaEditorPreferencePage which is called the first time you do a search.
STEPS 1) Self host Eclipse 2) Select Java Search 3) Enter the name of a class 4) Hit Search - Invalid Thread Access
Log: Wed Apr 03 08:57:31 EST 2002 4 org.eclipse.jdt.ui 1 Internal Error
The plugin can be activated in any thread and the plugin activation can result in initialization of the preference store. Therefore preference initialization may not access the Display.
*** Bug 15171 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** The illegal thread access can happen whenever getPreferenceStore is called from a non-UI thread (see also 15171). It calls JavaEditorPreferencePage.initDefaults that needs access to the Display to get the system colors.
Fix discussed with Kai is to get the system colors with a syncExec call.
This fix needs to go into the M5 stream. Build 20020508 + M5'.

Bug.Summery: NPE relaunching launch config
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20020402 I pulled down the debug history and selected an old launch (runtime workbench launch). The following NPE occurred.
java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.internal.launcher.WorkbenchLaunchConfigurationDelegate.launch(WorkbenchLaunchConfigurationDelegate.java:68) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:137) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.actions.RelaunchActionDelegate.relaunch(RelaunchActionDelegate.java:124) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetSelection(ActionContributionItem.java:407) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.handleWidgetEvent(ActionContributionItem.java:361) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem.access$0(ActionContributionItem.java:352) at org.eclipse.jface.action.ActionContributionItem$ActionListener.handleEvent(ActionContributionItem.java:47) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.EventTable.sendEvent(EventTable.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.notifyListeners(Widget.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.run(Workbench.java:738) at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run(InternalBootLoader.java:777) at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:319) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:190) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:549) at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:390) I believe the problem here is that I had a host with the J9 launching plugin and created a launch config for that VM type (J9).
When I updated my host, I forgot to put the J9 launching plugin back. This NPE occurred when I tried to launch a config with J9 set as the VM.
Users should be able to add and remove plugins without blowing up. We need to handle this.
I found the following in my log: Log: Wed Apr 03 09:30:27 CST 2002 4 org.eclipse.jdt.launching 4 VM type element with unknown id Log: Wed Apr 03 09:31:15 CST 2002 2 org.eclipse.core.resources 2 Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: org.eclipse.core.resources. java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.updateTable(PluginModelManager.java:104) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.handleModelsChanged(PluginModelManager.java:83) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.access$0(PluginModelManager.java:67) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager$1.modelsChanged(PluginModelManager.java:23) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.WorkspaceModelManager.fireModelProviderEvent(WorkspaceModelManager.java:178) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.WorkspaceModelManager.processModelChanges(WorkspaceModelManager.java:575) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.WorkspaceModelManager.resourceChanged(WorkspaceModelManager.java:538) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager$1.run(NotificationManager.java:123) at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.run(InternalPlatform.java:817) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java:395) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager.notify(NotificationManager.java:138) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.NotificationManager.deleting(NotificationManager.java:89) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.deleting(Workspace.java:683) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Resource.delete(Resource.java:435) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Project.delete(Project.java:304) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.wizards.imports.PluginImportOperation.createProject(PluginImportOperation.java:147) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.wizards.imports.PluginImportOperation.run(PluginImportOperation.java:103) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run(Workspace.java:1343) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.wizards.imports.PluginImportWizard$2.run(PluginImportWizard.java:130) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run(ModalContext.java:98) Re-assigning to PDE team since NPE happens in their code. I agree that NPE is not acceptable in any case. But you understand that there is a problem with saved information here: we persisted launch config (including the VM to use) and then you removed the VM out of the system. We should not allow you to launch then, but of course not with an NPE :-). Changing priority to regular - this is not a blocker. Fixed - PDE will report when stored JRE is missing and abort launching. Note that the problem here wasn't a missing JRE. The JRE was still installed on my system. The problem was that the plugin necessary to launch the JRE (org.eclipse.jdt.launching.j9) was missing. I understand. What made PDE to bomb was when it tried to locate IVMInstall instance using the name stored in the configuration. Since none of the VMs matched, it tried to access a null IVMInstall and caused a NPE. The fix was to show an error message and abort the launch.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20020402 I pulled down the debug history and selected an old launch (runtime workbench launch). The following NPE occurred.
I believe the problem here is that I had a host with the J9 launching plugin and created a launch config for that VM type (J9).
When I updated my host, I forgot to put the J9 launching plugin back. This NPE occurred when I tried to launch a config with J9 set as the VM.
Users should be able to add and remove plugins without blowing up. We need to handle this.
I found the following in my log: Log: Wed Apr 03 09:30:27 CST 2002 4 org.eclipse.jdt.launching 4 VM type element with unknown id Log: Wed Apr 03 09:31:15 CST 2002 2 org.eclipse.core.resources 2 Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: org.eclipse.core.resources.
Re-assigning to PDE team since NPE happens in their code. I agree that NPE is not acceptable in any case. But you understand that there is a problem with saved information here: we persisted launch config (including the VM to use) and then you removed the VM out of the system. We should not allow you to launch then, but of course not with an NPE :-). Changing priority to regular - this is not a blocker. Fixed - PDE will report when stored JRE is missing and abort launching. Note that the problem here wasn't a missing JRE. The JRE was still installed on my system. The problem was that the plugin necessary to launch the JRE (org.eclipse.jdt.launching.j9) was missing. I understand. What made PDE to bomb was when it tried to locate IVMInstall instance using the name stored in the configuration. Since none of the VMs matched, it tried to access a null IVMInstall and caused a NPE. The fix was to show an error message and abort the launch.

Bug.Summery: Cannot specify proxy arguements for J9 proxy
Bug.WithStack:
There is no configuration parameter to specify j9proxy arguments, such as the location of symbol files. Could you provide me with an example of the arguments? Are they specific to proxy launching, or JDI connecting? j9proxy allows you to define the symbol file locations for debugging jxe's. According to the j9proxy help the valid options are
Usage: j9proxy <vm host>:<vm port> <proxy port> <symbol file(s)>
vm host hostname or IP address where the target VM is running vm port debug port of the target VM proxy port port to connect the debugger to symbol file(s) symbol file(s) to read
Right now, the debug runner will automaticly set the vm host/vm port and proxy port, but there is no way to set the symbol file location. I am not looking for a UI to do it. Just a LaunchConfigurationAttribute will be fine. How are you launching the proxy? We do not have a launcher that does this. Our local VM runner for J9 does launch a proxy, and there is no place to specify J9 specific arguments. The j9 launching plug-in is not an official component of the SDK. We will not be completing this for 2.0. On the bright side, we do support a MAP of VM specific args in the launch configurations, and provide an extension point for a UI. SDK does not support J9 - This is an issue for WSDD, if desired. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Need to get full set of breakpoints hit from thread.
Bug.WithStack: When creating super adapters on top of the Java debug adapter we set hidden temporary breakpoints in order to control the Java debug adapter. If the user also sets a breakpoint at the same spot as one of our temporary breakpoints then when we get a suspend event due to a breakpoint from the Java thread we need to be able to ask the thread for the list of breakpoints that were hit. Currently we can only get one breakpoint from the thread. If we only see our temporary breakpoint which we might choose to ignore and don't see the user breakpoint then we will run away. Fixed. Please verify (also see new EventSetTests which I added) Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack: When creating super adapters on top of the Java debug adapter we set hidden temporary breakpoints in order to control the Java debug adapter. If the user also sets a breakpoint at the same spot as one of our temporary breakpoints then when we get a suspend event due to a breakpoint from the Java thread we need to be able to ask the thread for the list of breakpoints that were hit. Currently we can only get one breakpoint from the thread. If we only see our temporary breakpoint which we might choose to ignore and don't see the user breakpoint then we will run away. Fixed. Please verify (also see new EventSetTests which I added) Verified.

Bug.Summery: Add support for restaring the workbench
Bug.WithStack: A new API IWorkbench.restart() has been added to the platform. We should take advantage of it and offer to restart the workbench when performing install/update tasks that need restarting. *** Bug 11877 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Support added as far as calling IWorkbench.restart(). Moving to PDE to catch return code 23 in SlimLauncher and restart the workbench (to allow restart of the run-time instance during selfhosting). Implemented. PDE now continuously calls 'BootLoader.run' as long as the return code is 23. Otherwise, it drops from the loop and exits.
Bug.WithOutStack: A new API IWorkbench.restart() has been added to the platform. We should take advantage of it and offer to restart the workbench when performing install/update tasks that need restarting. *** Bug 11877 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Support added as far as calling IWorkbench.restart(). Moving to PDE to catch return code 23 in SlimLauncher and restart the workbench (to allow restart of the run-time instance during selfhosting). Implemented. PDE now continuously calls 'BootLoader.run' as long as the return code is 23. Otherwise, it drops from the loop and exits.

Bug.Summery: Method entry breakpoint enabled when neither exit or entry
Bug.WithStack:
Create a method entry breakpoint Set it to be neither exit or entry (becomes disabled) Set the hit count
The breakpoint shows as enabled This was broken when setHitCount() was optimized to set all attributes in a single setAttribute() call. This meant that the setHitCount() method was directly setting the enabled attribute instead of going through the setEnabled() method.
The side effect of this was to avoid the code in the JavaBreakpoint subclasses (JavaWatchpoint and JavaMethodBreakpoint) which does special handling of enablement.
I've returned the call to setEnabled() to the setHitCount() method. JavaWatchpoint and JavaMethodBreakpoint now get to manage their access/modification and entry/exit states again. Please verify. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Create a method entry breakpoint Set it to be neither exit or entry (becomes disabled) Set the hit count
The breakpoint shows as enabled This was broken when setHitCount() was optimized to set all attributes in a single setAttribute() call. This meant that the setHitCount() method was directly setting the enabled attribute instead of going through the setEnabled() method.
The side effect of this was to avoid the code in the JavaBreakpoint subclasses (JavaWatchpoint and JavaMethodBreakpoint) which does special handling of enablement.
I've returned the call to setEnabled() to the setHitCount() method. JavaWatchpoint and JavaMethodBreakpoint now get to manage their access/modification and entry/exit states again. Please verify. Verified.
